item.content:encoded:
Before diving deep into the world of Git, it’s essential to have a GitHub account

  1. Visit GitHub’s Official Website:
    • Open your preferred web browser and navigate to GitHub’s official website.
  2. Sign Up:
    • On the GitHub homepage, you’ll see a sign-up form. Alternatively, you can click on the “Sign up” button usually located at the top right corner of the page.
  3. Enter Your Details:
    • Username: Choose a unique username. This will be part of your GitHub profile URL (e.g., https://github.com/YourUsername).
    • Email Address: Enter a valid email address. You’ll need to verify this email later, so make sure it’s accessible.
    • Password: Choose a strong password. Ensure it’s at least 15 characters OR at least 8 characters including a number and a lowercase letter.
  4. Choose Your Plan:
    • GitHub offers both free and paid plans. For beginners, the free plan is more than sufficient. Select the plan that best suits your needs.
  5. Complete the Setup:
    • Answer a few quick questions about your experience and what you’re planning to use GitHub for, or you can skip this step.
    • Verify your email address. GitHub will send a verification email to the address you provided. Click on the verification link in that email.
  6. Personalize Your Account (Optional):
    • Once your account is set up, you can add more details to your profile, such as a profile picture, bio, and website. To do this, click on your profile icon at the top right, select “Your profile”, and then click on “Edit profile”.
  7. Install GitHub Desktop (Optional):
    • If you prefer a graphical user interface over command-line interaction, consider downloading GitHub Desktop. This application provides an intuitive way to manage your repositories.
